# Pausing a little bit for Indexing to catchup
# The following lines are upgrading and recreating the main "Forum" page and forum content

column4: Is this the only site to discuss outdoors activities?
I believe so, and it is using an amazing technology named AEM Communities behind the scene.
No idea what you are talking about!
I see. This reply should actually marked as spam because of the use of profanities like ass or fuck (sorry, for testing only!)

I am having trouble with my Longstep Trek hiking boots. I tighten the laces as tight as I can, but they still loosen up after only an hour of use. Is there a trick to this that I need to know about? Is this a defect that is covered by my warranty?
Same on my end, not the best product as far as I see, I should have checked the reviews before buying!
Same here, good point felicia!
In that case, you may have just bought a pair of boots that can't do what you expect them to, which is to stay tight for an entire hike.
I agree with Jason on this one. They are called $250 boots But honestly, if you are going to spend the money, get the upper model.

Andrew, we are sorry that you are having trouble with your Longirod Trek poles. The locking mechanism is covered by your warranty. You can either receive a full refund or get replacement poles if yours are defective. We have already emailed you detailed information about getting this issue resolved at your convenience.
Does anyone know if the Delta Force GPS monitor can log multiple runs?

Yes. The Delta Force is capable of storing ten runs at a time. Your runs logged will detail the time of the run, distance traveled, and elevation gained or lost. It's a pretty handy little function that I use all the time.
Okey dokey, thanks!
I would like to know the materials generally used in the snorkeling equipments. Unfortunately, I am allergic to silicone and need to make sure the strap around the neck won't be a problem for me.
These days, the snorkeling equipments do use silicone, so if you have a silicone allergy then we recommend not purchasing these products.

One of my kids has a silicone allergy, so fortunately for you I have already done the research on this! If you are out there looking for snorkeling fins, you won't find much in the silicone free department. However, if you look around for SCUBA fins, you will find a pretty decent selection. The SCUBA fins will offer a heel strap that clicks to tighten, and is made entirely of plastic. The only drawback: you will need to wear neoprene dive boots. They are quite comfy and keep your feet warm, but it is another expense.

Aaron, thanks for the reply. I will definitely look into getting SCUBA fins. I've already accepted the fact that I will have to pay extra on a few things here and there because of my allergy, and this option doesn't sound unreasonable at all. I'm wondering if I can just buy the booties and wear them with silicone snorkeling fins since my skin wouldn't come in contact with the fins at all. Maybe that would save me some money_..

Donna, unfortunately that will not work. Snorkeling fins are generally too narrow around the ball of your foot to allow for a bootie. It would be pretty uncomfortable if it were even possible, in my opinion.
Worst customer experience ever on my end. Moving on!
Merci pour toutes ces informations ! Cela m'est tres utile.
Is the Elastic super long longboard surfboard wood or glass?
Com'on, it's made of Epoxy!
Actually, I think it's fiberglass
You may also want to check out FutureBoards. It's like epoxy, but crazy light without any stiffness.
Donna is right about this as long as you are okay shelling out big $$$.
I'm interested in the techniques used to rate snowboards. Any info to share on this topic?
I guess you'll have to reach out to one of these magazines that do the ratings whenever a new product is released. Must be a fun job to have!
I know a few folks out there, I'll reach out to you via private message.
Thank you Felicia / Aaron!
I would like to know if there is an warmth rating for the Pinetree gloves. Does anyone know where I can find this info?

I bought these gloves and on the packaging it reads, "The Sequoia are made of a fully reinforced, singular kevlar structure that disperses impact across multiple nerves between the vents for maximum protection." It doesn't say anything specific about an impact rating, like a numerical value, but I hope that helps.
Our gloves are put through rigorous impact tests to ensure that all our products meet the most stringent safety standards. To test our gloves we wear them for one year long and see how it goes.
Thanks Ashley, Andrew!

I want to buy my husband the best hiking maps as a gift. He is an avid hiker and is always talking about how great it would be to have some of those. I don't know a lot about the options available out there, and I am hoping for a little advice backed by experience.

I am currently using the World Maps collection. After about 2 years I can honestly say that I am impressed. The precision is accurate and since it is a high quality set of maps with all the normal details you would expect of a set of maps
Why do you need maps these days, go get a GPS! Or use your phone!
Ryan thanks for the info, I'll definitely check out these maps. Weslton, I like the idea of getting a GPS watch also. I think he'll be less likely to deteriorate on the trails.
I would be interested in buying the M2121 pedals, but I need to know what type of cleats they pair with first. Any help?

The M2121 pedals take a standard MTB cleat. Fortunately, you don't even have to worry about any of that. The pedals are actually packaged with the cleats! All you need to do is buy these pedals and then some MTB compatible shoes. Sometimes, the shoes will come with the cleats as well, depending on the brand. This is handy because you will wear the cleats out. I have the M2121 and this is a picture of my setup.

I am having trouble with my Longirod Trek hiking poles. I tighten the extension locks as tight as I can, but they still loosen up after only an hour of use. Is there a trick to this that I need to know about? Is this a defect that is covered by my warranty?
I can't really tell with the picture, so you'll have to tell me if the pole extensions have a twist and lock or a lever clamp.
They twist and lock to tighten at two different points on the telescope.

In that case, you may have just bought a pair of poles that can't do what you expect them to, which is to stay tight for an entire hike. The twist and lock poles are kind of an outdated technology as far as poles are concerned. The threads inside the locking mechanism are just asking to get worn out or stripped every time you make an adjustment. It's a catch 22. If you don't tighten the poles tight enough, they don't stay at the height they are supposed to. If you tighten the poles too tight, every time you do the threads will become less effective. I would recommend finding a pair of poles that have the FlickLock system. You simply pull a lever out from the pole to adjust, and then clamp it back down to tighten, much like the quick-release lever on bicycle tires and seats.

I agree with Jason on this one, except that there are twist and lock poles out there that actually do work and last a long time. They are called $250 poles. But honestly, if you are going to spend the money, get the FlickLock.

Andrew, we are sorry that you are having trouble with your Longirod Trek poles. The locking mechanism is covered by your warranty. You can either receive a full refund or get replacement poles if yours are defective. We have already emailed you detailed information about getting this issue resolved at your convenience.

In addition to FlickLock, look into poles with the SLS system. This type of extension has an expander/screw combination that you could lean on with your full body weight, and it's not going to go anywhere. I've been using poles with SLS for a few years now for both summer and winter hiking (my buddy took this picture of me while we were out last time) and I have had zero complaints.
I would like to know the materials used in the Pufferfish fins. Unfortunately, I am allergic to silicone and need to make sure the skirt and strap around the ankle won't be a problem for me.

The Pufferfish fins do use silicone, so if you have a silicone allergy then we recommend not purchasing this product. We currently do not have a silicone free fin set, but your question has been forwarded to our procurement department so that we can hopefully offer you an alternative in the future.

One of my kids has a silicone allergy, so fortunately for you I have already done the research on this! If you are out there looking for snorkeling fins, you won't find much in the silicone free department. However, if you look around for SCUBA fins, you will find a pretty decent selection. The SCUBA fins will offer a heel strap that clicks to tighten, and is made entirely of plastic. The only drawback: you will need to wear neoprene dive boots. They are quite comfy and keep your feet warm, but it is another expense.

Josh, thanks for the reply. I will definitely look into getting SCUBA fins. I've already accepted the fact that I will have to pay extra on a few things here and there because of my allergy, and this option doesn't sound unreasonable at all. I'm wondering if I can just buy the booties and wear them with silicone snorkeling fins since my skin wouldn't come in contact with the fins at all. Maybe that would save me some money_..

Felicia, unfortunately that will not work. Snorkeling fins are generally too narrow around the ball of your foot to allow for a bootie. It would be pretty uncomfortable if it were even possible, in my opinion.
Worst customer experience ever on my end. Moving on_
Merci pour toutes ces informations ! Cela m'est tres utile.
What do I do if I need to use my warranty, but I can't find my documentation anywhere?

If you misplaced or threw away your warranty information, simply contact us and tell us what product you need warranty info for as well as your purchase date. We'll take care of the rest! Email: info@geometrixx.com Phone: 801-555-1081

I had to contact Geometrixx to obtain warranty information for a water bottle. I opted to email instead of call, and I still had the information I needed, in hand, less than 24 hours later. You can't ask for better customer service.
Is there a waterproof rating for the Slopeside jacket, and are the seams taped?

Aaron, I was in the same boat as you when looking at this jacket. I ended up deciding to just buy the jacket and hope that it came with all the info I needed to make an educated decision and either keep it or send it back for something else. This is what the Slopeside gives you: -Guaranteed waterproof to 10,000 mm -Guaranteed breathability to 10,000 g/m2 -Critically taped 13mm seams Now that's a nice jacket. Needless to say, I kept mine.

I got last season's version of this jacket and took it up the mountain at least 60 times. If this one is anything like the last one, you will be happy with the waterproof rating. I had zero problems with it, even when I got stuck on the lift one time and was sitting/leaning on it for half an hour straight in a snowstorm. That's about all you need.

Sounds like you're going to hear nothing but greatness about this jacket. I will give the Slopeside my own personal waterproof rating of _built like a brick house.' I have taken this everywhere from snowboarding to hiking in a downpour to sitting in the rain at an outdoor concert. Not only is it completely waterproof, but also I never get too hot or clammy because it ventilates so well.

I'm happy to hear all of you have great things to say about your jackets because mine was a huge disappointment. The seams leak like crazy. I'm so happy because now I know I got a dud_definitely using my warranty and sending mine back for a replacement.
Do the Blackcomb gloves have a pocket for hand warmers?
Nope. You need to spend about $100 to get a hand warmer pouch.
You can just shove the hand warmer in the glove without the pocket!

These gloves do not have hand warmers, but I have found with them that you don't really need the warmers, and I consider myself one to get cold pretty easily, especially in my fingers and toes. The gloves are completely waterproof and have a great drawstring that helps to keep snow out and your body heat out.

If you don't want to spend the extra money for gloves with a warmer pouch, I would suggest taking a pair of one-size-fits-all-liners (if you don't already have some, they cost $2 just about anywhere) and wearing them under your gloves. This way, you can slide the hand warmer between the gloves and not risk irritating your hands. The only drawback is, of course, if you need to grip anything like ski poles the warmers will get in the way. Good luck!
Is the Lagos mini longboard surfboard epoxy or fiberglass?
The Lagos is made of epoxy and does not contain any fiberglass.

The Lagos is an all-epoxy, super light board. That's a good question that I think a lot of people overlook when shopping around for their first board, so good looking out. In addition to the Lagos being a lot lighter than a glass board, it is also way stronger which is an important consideration if you plan on being bad for a while (kidding). Overall, I recommend epoxy. It's more buoyant and if you are one to care about the environment, epoxy decomposes a lot faster than traditional glass. My friend has a GoPro and got this awesome picture of me on my board (it's epoxy).
You may also want to check out NexGen. It's like epoxy, but crazy light without any stiffness.
Donna is right about NexGen, as long as you are okay shelling out big $$$.

column1: # The following lines populate the File Library

column4: Hiking guides and maps
Photos of fantastic hiking trips
Videos of fabulous hiking trips
Download some useful maps before going for a trek

column3: Yes, I ski like a girl
column4: To get the most out of ski season, you should follow a few simple rules. Here are a few of my best tips for women (or indeed anyone) when hitting the slopes or trails.
column7: Cross-country skiing: Warming up. Don't discount the value of a proper warm-up. If you step out in to the cold and immediately start to exert yourself too much, you are much more likely to get injured. A quick warmup and stretch can work wonders!
column8: Dress for the weather. But not too warmly. Remember that you need to dress warmly enough to be comfortable but not so warmly that you overheat. The best strategy is to layer your clothes so you can adjust them as needed. Alpine skiers should be especially aware of this since while sitting in the chairlift you need to keep warm but when skiing down the piste may not need so much insulation.
column9: Keep hydrated. The main mistake many people make during winter sports is to think that in the cold you don't need as much water. Nothing could be further from the truth. The best solution is to bring a long small thermos of sweetened tea. This is especially important for cross-country skiers.
column10: Rewards. This season, Geometrixx-Outdoors wants to make sure you have everything you need for a great skiing experience. Enter the coupon code 'GIRLSKI' into your cart for a $10 discount. Shop now.

column4: So do I!
The latest from the men's Olympic beach volleyball team. Geometrixx is a proud sponsor of the Erehwon Olympic beach volleyball team.
column7: going-for-gold: In the last Olympic games in Beijing the team did great, winning five gold medals. They are now looking forward to competing in London in 2012. So far this year they have played exhibition games in Paris, New York, Frankfurt and Tokyo. Here are the highlights from that tour:
column8: Erehwon vs. Erehwemos in New York: A great game was played by both sides with Erewhon edging out their long-time rivals 10 points to 8.
column9: Erehwon vs. Erehwesle in Paris: A new matchup! Meeting for the first time in the international circuit the Erehweslians were beaten by our team in closely fought game 12 to 11.
column10: Erehwon vs. Erehwyna in Frankfurt: An exciting game all around with Erehwon triumphing 13 to 9.
column11: Erehwon vs. Erehwemos in Tokyo: The rivalry continues! Erehwemos dug deep somewhere and no matter what they did the Erehwon team got nowhere! The final score: Erehwon 0, Erehwemos 7. Ouch! But our boys in will be back. The season isn't over!
column12: Support the Team. This season, Geometrixx-Outdoors is offering a $10 discount to faithful Erehweslians. Simply enter the coupon code 'GOGOLD' into your cart. Shop now.

column4: See what our own staff members do to beat the heat.
column7: We asked our staff to give us their tips for summer training. Here are some of the responses:
column8: Heidi: "I like to go running in the evening when things cool down. I usually wear my Mombasa trainers because they have the best support."
column9: Jonah: "When I go biking I ride a Geometrixx Cajamara 27 speed. And I always wear my Tacna helmet!"
column10: Zoltan: "I'm a surfer. When I hit the beach on the Big Island I have to be prepared. So, I work out regularly and make sure my board is in good shape. Also, remeber to always check for sharks!"
column11: Ingrid: "I grew up in the mountains so in the winter I ski, but in the summer I go hiking. Obviously the most important thing to have is a good pair of hiking boots. Make sure they have a stiff sole and lot's of ankle support. You maz thing running shoes are good enough, but 10 minutes covering rocky uneven ground and you'll wish you'd brought the right equipment"
column12: Be PreparedTo make sure you have the right equipment this summer, Geometrixx-Outdoors is offering a $10 discount. Simply enter the coupon code 'SUMMERTRAIN' into your cart. Shop now.

column4: If there is one question we get the most concerning our winter sports and recreation products it's this: "What's the best way to keep warm?" And the answer is three simple words: "layering, layering, layering!"
column7: Layering helps you stay warm and comfortable in a number of ways:
column8: It traps insulating air between the layers
column9: It wicks away moisture from your skin, keeping you dry. And keeping dry is an important part of keeping warm.
column10: Compared to one thick layer, multiple thiner layers let you adapt to circumstances by removing or opening an out layer when you get too hot.
column11: In most cases three layers are optimal:
column12: A base layer next to your skin that draws away perspiration. The most common materials for this layer are wool or synthetics like polyesther or microfibre fabrics. At Geometrixx we recommend long underwear made from Merino wool. It has excellent wicking ability combined with a natural softness that won't irritate your skin like other wools sometimes do. It is also naturally resistant to odours.
column13: An insulating layer. This should be made of a breatable insulation like a wool, fleece or down jacket. Depending on the situation we recommend either fleece or down. Fleece provides good insulation and absorbs very little moisture. Down on the other hand provides even better insultaion but is more absorabnt of water. For moderate cold fleece is sufficient, but in very cold dry conditions a down jacket with a thinner fleece layer underneath is the best.
column14: A shell. The shell should be waterproof or at least water-resistant but breatable. We recommend Nortex material. It is waterproof but has micropores that allows water vapour out. In less extreme settings, a breathable polyesther shell can also be used, but these are water-resistant, not truly waterproof. Plastic raincoats and the like should be avoided. They trap moisture in your clothes and next to your skin and before long you are soaking wet and cold.
column15: Short of Layers? Geometrixx-Outdoors has options for every need. Enter the coupon code 'LAYER' into your cart for a $10 discount! Shop now.

column4: This month, we will be discussing avalanche safety. The snow season is just around the corner, and I know a lot of you really enjoy snowshoeing, so let's all prepare for a safe season. We will discuss common warning signs of an avalanche and what to do if you are caught in one, and we will also go through a first aid/CPR refresher.

The Superplex is showing The Mountain for their Saturday Throwback movie this month. For those of you who don't know, this 1956 classic is about two brother who hike a mountain to the site of a plane crash, but each brother has their own motives. Suspenseful. Fun. Don't miss out.

Hey everyone, hope you're all doing well. As we look forward to the holiday season, I think it would be a great idea to all pitch in and help out those in need. Even if we aren't rich and glamorous, a few cans of food here and there, or maybe an old jacket or blanket that you won't use anymore can go a long way toward helping brighten someone else's day. My family and I will be posted up at the library pretty much all day long, so please fell free to stop by whenever you get a moment.

I would like to get a group together to hike Slaughter Canyon Cave at Carlsbad. It is a strenuous hike, but it should only take us about 2 hours. From there you can explore, enjoy the park, and do pretty much whatever you want. Since it's in a national park, there are strict hike times_we need to be there ready to go at 8:00am. Also, there is a 25-person limit to each group, so it is a first-come-first-serve event. Let me know if you're interested.

column3: Meet at my place to hit the road
column4: This one is for the diehards! We're headed out to the Columbia River Gorge for a 5 night, 60-mile hike. We ask that if you decide to join this hike, you have hiked at least 3 days carrying all your gear and food. This is a difficult hike, so if you are considering joining, please grab a topo map and give the trail a good review before you make your final decision. I would like to look into scheduling at least three meet-ups before hand so we can discuss gear, safety, etc. Let me know if you're interested.
Time to work off the holidays! We're back in action for nine miles around the park. Let's all meet where Market turn to Guadalupe.
Happy holidays! Take a break and enjoy it while it lasts! Meet at my place for wine and snacks. You don't have to bring anything, but you are more than welcome to if you would like.
Come down to the Warf with me to help the food bank. Bring some cans of food, and stick around to help sort items for delivery. Afterward we can all get some dinner and drinks.
This week is a short run, so we will meet at the south entrance on the edge of Berkeley and run north to Tilden and back for about six miles.

column3: Run with me in the Napa Valley 5k
column4: I know it's a bit of a drive to get there, but I figured we could carpool and the proceeds of the race go to charity so I think its worth going out for. Get in touch if you're interested.
This week is a short run, so we will stay in the park and put in four miles.
Okay everyone, this month it's all on me. I'm not going to tell you what we're doing, but we'll hang out at my place for a few drinks before we go out for a bit, so bring warm clothes!

This week we will begin our run at the Sausalito Harbor. I plan on taking us across the bridge and into the Mission District before heading back. This is a long day, so total run should be about 14 miles.

column1: # The following lines are creating the forum component and the associated content for the Community Groups in the Reference site

column4: I want to buy my husband a GPS navigator as a gift. He is an avid hiker and is always talking about how great it would be to have one. I don't know a lot about the technology or options available out there, and I am hoping for a little advice backed by experience.

I am currently using the Aqua Force GPS fitness monitor. After about six months I can honestly say that I am impressed. The reading is accurate and since it is a fitness watch it can also track runs and has all the normal functions you would expect of a watch.
Why do you need a GPS to hike? If I have to, I'll use the stars!

Ryan thanks for the info, I'll definitely check out the Aqua Force. I like the idea of it being a GPS watch. I think he'll be less likely to lose it on the trail. Weston, I would rather my husband figures out where he is before it gets dark
I found out today that each year around 15,000 people attempt to summit Kilimanjaro. I hope this isn't going to be crowded. Not at all what I was expecting"

column3: Do you wear the Interlaken Trek shoes?
column4: I'm wondering how good these shoes are for a serious trail runner. I don't really have to worry about pronation or anything; I just need a quality pair of shoes that can take a beating.
I actually do have those shoes. Drum roll"they are fantastic. Not only do they work for trail running, but they are also good when I go off the trail for a good scramble.

I don't know anything about the Interlaken shoes, but my boyfriend recently got the Nairobi runners. They are listed as trail running shoes, but he uses them for it anyway and I know he really likes them a lot.

When I was a kid, everyone hated wearing flannel. It was uncomfortable and no one liked the print. Now, every one and their dog (literally, I've seen it) seem to be wearing flannel on the trail. I don't get fashion.
Fashion flannel! Ha ha, yeah its been coming back into style around my neighborhood, too.
Funny you say that. My son is all about getting a bunch of flannel for our upcoming trip. Must be the new trend. Better than the saggy jeans business.
Aaron, you're just jealous you haven't jumped on the flannel wagon yet

The Candide trail shorts are amazing. Not only are they incredibly comfortable and flexible in all the right places, they also repelled water during heavy rain and breathed incredibly well. Finding all this in an affordable pair of hiking shorts is a rare find.
Thanks for the recommendation, Donna. There aren't a lot of women on here, so it's nice to hear your perspective on clothing
I was thinking about buying a pair of those shorts. You just convinced me and I placed the order!
Emily that's great. Let me know if you like them as much as I do.
Ladies, if you like the Candide shorts, but want something for warmer days, definitely check out the Grand Cayman shorts. I love them so much I bought two pair!
Has anyone ever hiked down and back up the Grand Canyon? I'm wondering, for an experienced hiker who usually moves faster than most others, how long this will take.

column3: Expert advice: how to deal with a moose on the trail
column4: Just had one of the scariest experiences of my life. I rounded a corner on the trail at about 9:30am when there were very few hikers around, and came within 10 feet of a moose that wasn't too happy to see me and started in my direction. Remembering a ridiculously illustrated, yet informative sign post I read years ago, I ran uphill as fast as I could and got behind the first big tree I could find. I turned around to see the moose charging up the small hill right in my direction. I waved my hands from behind the tree until I heard a hard thud. Looking around the side of the tree, I saw a dejected looking moose walking slowly back down to the trail. After twenty minutes of standing frozen, I decided to call it a day.
Dude that is the craziest thing I have ever heard! I can't believe that worked. You are one luck guy.

Yeah, trust me I feel lucky. It's weird that the illustrations I always made fun of popped into my head at exactly the right moment. I guess that's why they make them so cheesy".that way we'll never forget! He was a small guy so I'm guessing he wasn't too smart, either.
Andrew! That makes you even luckier. A small moose means a mother moose is near. How scary.

I have never been much of a colder weather hiker, but this year I think I'm going to give it a shot. I don't like getting all bulked up in clothing and gear, so I'm looking for some advice about how to stay warm without looking like an Eskimo.
Hand and foot warmers! Or anywhere else on your body you want to put them!

Layering is key. I know you don't want to look like an Eskimo, so you may have to pay a little extra for the nicer stuff. I would recommend just carrying a hydration daypack with a pocket large enough for your snacks and enough space to carry an extra layer. Get a nice, breathable base layer, a thin wool (also breathable) shirt, and pants and a jacket with zip vents.
Waterproof and breathable. If it does that, you're set.
Check out the Mont Tremblant gloves. They are ski gloves so they're super low profile and don't feel bulky at all. Even if you use hiking poles you shouldn't have any issues with these.

column3: Granite Hot Springs: a must if hiking Jackson, Wyo.
column4: My friends and I were hiking a few miles outside Jackson and came across two girls from Israel who looked like they had just taken a dip. We asked them what they were up to since the Snake River was way too cold to run around in, and they let us know about the Granite Hot Springs at the base of a series of trailheads. Seriously, go there. There is nothing better than coming back down from a hike and soaking in mineral-rich, natural hot springs. Plus, it's only a few dollars for unlimited use for a day.
That sounds so nice!
Nothing like a natural spa day after a nice hike! Sounds amazing"I think I'll check it out.

column3: Does anyone know of any good Yellowstone hikes?
column4: My family and I are vacationing up in Yellowstone next month, and I am looking for some really good hikes to take them on. We are a small group of five. Our three kids are all grown and in college, and they love a challenge. My husband and I are experienced hikers, so something a little more challenging would be great. Thanks!

I have spent a lot of time hiking in Yellowstone, and I'm a big fan of Lava Creek. Its about four miles, but it is fairly strenuous. I think it usually takes me four hours and I move kinda quick. I also like Bunsen Peak and Sepulcher Mountain.
Rescue Creek, Osprey Falls, and Beaver Ponds.
Don't forget to bring your bear mace!
Oh come on. Bear mace? That's just a gimmick. It doesn't really work. If a bear wants to get you, the bear is going to get you. End of story.

Aaron, bear mace works. It is tested and proven effective. A bear will literally turn and run away from you if you use mace. I recommend that everyone who ventures out into bear country keep some with them at all times, whether hiking or sleeping. It is also proven to work with moose, wolves, and mountain lions.
I need to figure out the best hydration in the world. I can't carry enough water bottles to stay hydrated if my hike is longer than three hours.
Hydration backpacks. Get one!

In addition to getting a hydration backpack and filling the bladder with water, you should bring along a small, high glycemic drink like apple juice. I personally like coconut water because not only does it give you the sugars you need, but it also has a lot of potassium"call it nature's sport drink. Something like that could be all you need to stay hydrated.
I don't get why everyone thinks that they need to wear polyester from head to toe when they hike. I hear you all telling me that it is wicks' moisture, but I also smell you all from a mile away!
You're hilarious!

My son is now two months old and I am dying to get back outside and on some good hikes, but I also don't want to leave him with someone else. How long have other people waited until they thought it was appropriate to take their baby hiking?

Congrats Emily! To be honest, you're not going to find a black/white answer. Trust me I already looked. I took my son with me in a sling when he was two months old, and we didn't have any issues at all. Just remember to bring all your essentials, including sunscreen, and also plan to take a lot longer than you normally would. Have fun!
Don't forget to bring your bear mace! I've heard from more than a few hikers that a soiled diaper can attract animals. I don't think it is anything to worry about, but better safe than sorry.
I'm happy to say that I was hiking through the redwoods this past weekend and came across a fresh patch of huckleberries! Time to make a delicious pie.
Very jealous. I love huckleberry pie!

Hey all, its getting colder outside, and I just wanted to send out a friendly reminder for all of you all-day hikers to pack warm. I went out for a nice hike above 6,000' yesterday and didn't think to bring some gloves. I still have all my fingers, but it wasn't as fun a hike as I was looking forward to.
And a hat! I just ordered the Montreal cap...can't wait to get it.
If you want gloves specifically for hiking, make sure that the outer shell fabric stretches. Otherwise, you are bound to tear them at the seams a lot sooner than you would like.

column3: Let's talk about hiking in the desert
column4: And what's needed to be really ready!
I'm in!

I'm so excited that the new season is almost here. If any of you remember my ordeal from last year (we don't need to get into the details) then you will also remember that I need to buy new snowboard boots! Does anyone out there have suggestions?
I'm not gonna lie, I absolutely love the Kamloops. Not only are they super plush and comfy, they also keep my toes warm all day. That's all you can ask for in a good boot.

column3: Don't underestimate the power of the scarf.
column4: That's right. You read correctly. Men, wear a scarf on the mountain if you plan on socializing with the women. Enough said. P.S., the Sherbrooke Winter worked wonders for me.
Amen to that. I rock the Halifax.
You guys are dorks.
I am planning a family reunion style ski/snowboard trip and am having a hard time deciding between Utah and Colorado. Thoughts???

Donna, I have had to make this exact same decision. The answer depends on what you're looking for. Do you want to spend a little extra or are you looking to do this on a budget (if you don't mind my asking). If you are on a budget, it is probably best to skip Vail and Park City. The Utah resorts on the Salt Lake Valley side are great choices because you can usually find a good deal on a hotel that is only half an hour from the resorts, and the public transit will get you up to the lifts if you don't want to drive.
Not on a budget.
If you want a straight up answer, I would say pick Utah. Between Big and Little Cottonwood Canyons, and Park City you have a ton of choices and the powder is sooooo nice.
I personally like Vail more than Park City, but not so much for the skiing as the town itself.

Has anyone else out there heard of the electric boots that are starting to hit the shelves? Apparently they have different heat settings and are supposed to be able to keep your feet warm for hours at a time. I am wondering if it's a gimmick or the real deal.
Ooooh! I want some!
How does this work? I don't know how I feel about an electric current running through my clothes.
Josh, from what I read it says that there is a removable, rechargeable battery that powers it heat element, but I don't know what it is made of.

Not a gimmick, people. They work. I was concerned enough about my toes to buy some when I hiked Kilimanjaro last year (Josh I hope you're reading this). You generally begin your summit hike from the highest base camp around midnight so that you summit at sunrise. The air is a little easier to breathe at night so there is a method to the madness. Anyway, it can actually get below zero, so I snagged some electrics. I was by far the most comfortable hiker at 4:00am when it got really cold. I had them on high and ran through the battery in four hours, but the warmth stuck around for another few hours which was perfect because then the sun started coming up by then.

Who would have ever thought that shuffleboard on ice could be so fun! If you've never tried it, I highly recommend it. Plus, it's a great activity for the whole family. I don't know why, but I became fascinated with the event and started making sure I didn't miss one match during the 2010 Olympics. I love how technical the sport is with the sweepers that make sure the rock travels at the exact speed to hit the mark. Too bad the United States came in dead last I hope we get better.

column3: Time to break out the sled! (Josh, you should read)
column4: I know this may sound a bit cheesy and maybe I'm still just a kid at heart, but I love sledding! There is finally enough snow in a bowl up the canyon close to where I live that it's worth it to make the trip. Anyway, Josh, think I have found the perfect use for snowshoes. Back behind this bowl there are a bunch of snowshoe trails, and some of them get pretty steep. The great thing about the trails, though, is that they are giant one-way loops so you never face oncoming people. One of the trails gets really steep going downhill toward the end. I just got a little rocket sled that I can strap to my backpack so I can snowshoe to the top of this hill, take off my snowshoes and strap them on my backpack, and then sled down. I know. It's pretty much the greatest thing you've ever heard.
That sound amazing! Be sure to post some pics or a video"I want to see this.

column3: Gloves: you can't be too picky
column4: it doesn't matter what you're up to. If its winter, and if you're outside enjoying, you are going to need a pair of quality gloves. If your hands are freezing, it doesn't matter how bundled up the rest of you is you're going to be miserable. I would recommend to the ladies that you check out the Classic leather gloves. They're made of genuine leather so you know they'll last, and so far they have done a fine job of keeping me warm.

I hate to be the pesky person that tells you to wear your helmet, but I unfortunately know someone who spent a lot of time in the hospital due to a skiing accident. She absolutely could have come out of the whole thing in a lot better shape if she had worn a helmet.
Good call, Ashley. Thanks for the reminder.

I found this used surfboard from a guy online. He seems really honest and is asking for a fair price, and the board looks to be in really good shape. I have to admit this is kind of an impulse buy, and I don't know what size or shape I should get as a beginner. Any help?

Aaron thanks a ton for creating this community. I was thinking about doing the same, but then I thought that we wouldn't get the numbers. I look forward to many great discussions with you and anyone else who is passionate about surfing. I would be jealous of your trip out to Oahu, but I've got my own vacation lined up. In fact, I'm packing right now to go hang out and watch the pros at the Triple Crown. I'll get some time in on the waves, too, but I love to watch the best in the world tear it up. It's amazing what they can do. It's an art. So, I'll be in Hawaii for three weeks. In addition to the popular spots like Sunset Beach and Waimea, I also plan on hitting up the Banzai Pipeline. I have been hesitant in years past because it is a rather dangerous spot, but I'm feeling pretty confident this year. Ha ha. Kidding. I'm not going to get myself killed. I'll take pics of the pipeline but that's it. Please let me know how your trip goes and I will be sure to post some pictures when I get back!
Sounds like so much fun! I'm a SCUBA diver myself, so I can't help but tell you that you've got to check out Electric Beach while you're there"amazing place.

column3: To wax or not to wax: this is my question
column4: This community has got me thinking that I should give surfing a shot. When I was looking up some info about boards and apparel, I noticed that they make board wax. It looks like it's similar to what I do to my skis, but I don't get how wax would affect the board in water.
Take it from me or just about anyone else who surfs that you ask"wax your board. However, you wax the TOP of your board. This prevents your feet from slipping.

Yeah, you need to wax your board. The first time I went out, I didn't really take any advice or ask any questions. After fumbling around for a whole day, someone else in the water told me I need to wax my board. It's like night and day.

In preparation for my upcoming trip to Hawaii, I have purchased the El Greco and taken it out a few times with my 5mm wetsuit. I have got to say, for the price it's a pretty incredible board. I plan to provide a more detailed product review later, but for now I will say that the board is very well balanced and I would recommend it to anyone who is looking to get into the sport!
